result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.addlTxt: 8:32 AM Defendant Daniel James Houle appeared by video, in custody from ACJ.  Attorney Rachel E. Pisors appeared by video for Daniel James Houle.  Attorney Lynne K Van Hollen appeared by video for State of Wisconsin.  Cases 21CF252, 20CF70, 20CF176, 22CF92, and 21CF229.  Cases here for def motion to modify bail.  Court has reviewed motion.  Atty asking to continue to consider fact that def has not been able to pay bond, has been sitting since June, would like to go and receive treatment.  Court circumstances have not changed, request to get out and go to treatment, bail is not a rehabilitative program, motion is denied.  Motion hearing scheduled for November it remains on the calendar.
Email sent to ACJ advising def has court on Oct 24;  ka
Motion hearing on October 24, 2022 at 08:30 am.

Attorney Ruth Kressel appeared by video for State of Wisconsin. Cases 20CF70, 20CF176, 21CF229, 21CF252, and 22CF92. Atty will have motion filed by close of business today.

2:01 PM Defendant Daniel James Houle appeared by video, in custody in custody from ACJ.  Attorney Rachel E. Pisors appeared by video for Daniel James Houle.  Attorney Lynne K Van Hollen appeared by video for State of Wisconsin.  Cases 20CF176, 21CF229, 21CF252, 22CF92, and 20CF70.  20CF70 here for motion hearing, 22CF92 here for initial appearance, and all other cases here for STC.  State did not prepare for motion hearing thought it was supposed to be in November.  Letters from Atty asking for motion date in November will put 20CF70 back on calendar for November.  22CF92 def has recv'd copy of compliant, waives reading, waiver of prelim hearing on file.  Court accepts the waiver.  Probable cause that def committed a felony in Ashland county bound over for arraignment.  State just filed information now.  Atty waives reading of information, def pleas NG, noted.  Motion to modify bail, Atty comments, State comments, court denies motion.  If def posts cash needs to appear in person.
Status conference scheduled for October 17, 2022 at 02:00 pm.

records.addlTxt: 11:06 AM Defendant Daniel James Houle appeared by video, in custody from ACJ.  Attorney Lynne K Van Hollen appeared by video for State of Wisconsin.  Attorney Rachel E. Pisors appeared by video for Daniel James Houle.  20CF70, 20CF176, 21CF229, 21CF252, and 22CF92.  Here for motion to modify bond, there is another motion later this week scheduled.  Attorney, comments on the motion for bond modification, bond set approximately a year and half ago.  Court advises attorney that on case 22CF92 attorney is not listed on and separate $1000 cash bail on that case.  On remaining other cases there is a $750 cash bail which is posted in 4 other pending cases.  Attorney asks to appear specially on case 22CF92, Court agrees.  Attorney, continues to comment on bail/bond.  State does not agree, comments on bail/bond.  Atty comments.  Court, comments on motion, posted $750 cash and released to community and recently picked up with new charges.  Court denies motion.  Older cases scheduled for hearing on 7/21 at 2pm dates remain on calendar 22CF92 will be and initial appearance.
Motion hearing on July 18, 2022 at 11:00 am.

Def shall not possess or consume any mind-altering substances meaning alcoholic beverages, controlled substances, inhalants, synthetic marijuana, or similar substances and/or over the counter medications used contrary to label instructions, or prescription medications not taken in compliance with a prescription issued to the defendant.  Def is not to go into any place where mind altering substances are present, maintained, sold or consumed, except defendant may enter a convenience store or grocery store, even if alcohol is sold there.
